items.0: Regular stand-ups: review results, issues, actions
items.1: Brainstorm: diverge and converge on ideas
items.2: Negotiation: align interests and reach agreement

diversity.h2: Meetings are diverse—negotiation is all about bargaining
diversity.p1: Change the objective, and the valuable output changes too. In negotiation, the bargaining itself is the core.

items.0: 1-on-1: results review, next goals, sharing challenges

example.block: Company A: Your previous product had a bug—it caused us real trouble. You owe us; deliver this by next week. Price is $1,000.\nOur company: We’ll push internally to deliver by next week. In return, can we raise it to $1,200? Please consider.\nCompany A: If you can guarantee next-week delivery, we’ll consider it. Send a reply by email today.
example.p1: Keeping these “key rounds” in the original wording lets decision-makers judge reasonableness with full context.

hero.h1: Why Minutes.AI helps you write the best negotiation minutes
hero.tagline: Negotiation is a contest of interests. Strong minutes don’t just list decisions and to-dos—they also capture context and tone. Here’s the approach and how to put it into practice with Minutes.AI.

items.0: Lists decisions without reasons or storyline
items.1: Unclear who asked for what and where concessions were made
items.2: Ambiguity around what’s unagreed or parked

items.1: Reasons, assumptions, and risks recorded close to each decision
items.2: Clear split of agreed/not agreed/parked with owners and due dates

limits.p1: Sticking to “discussion/decisions/action items/open issues” often drops background, tone, and the history of concessions. The result: misunderstandings, extra back-and-forth, and the risk of “said/not said.”

nav.current: Why Minutes.AI helps you write the best negotiation minutes

negotiation.p1: In short: protecting and growing your company’s interests. It isn’t a one-way announcement; you search for common ground by trading “demands” and “concessions” across terms like deadline, price, scope, and risk.

recap.focus: This time, we dive deep into negotiation.

p1.pre: Last time we showed how AI minutes can work for any kind of meeting. If you’re curious,

points.0: Meetings are diverse, so the optimal minutes format depends on the goal.
points.1: Generic templates help, but the detail level should be tuned to the use case.
points.2: From a “record to read” to a “plan to act.”
points.3: Minutes.AI adapts its output to the meeting’s objective.

seo.description: Negotiations need minutes that capture decisions, tasks, context, tone, and the history of concessions. A practical guide with Minutes.AI.

ld.description: The essence of negotiation in your minutes: demands, concessions, and context—with Minutes.AI.

why.h2: Why Minutes.AI is strong for negotiation

items.0: Summarizes demand/concession exchanges and preserves key passages verbatim (avoids “said/not said”).
items.2: Documents reasons, assumptions, and risks right next to decisions.
items.3: Separates agreed/not agreed/parked and assigns owners and deadlines.
items.4: Maps counterpart requests to your commitments for clear tracking.

wrap.p: Negotiation minutes are stronger when they keep the back-and-forth and the context—not just decisions. That speeds judgment and reduces rework. Make it your standard with Minutes.AI.
